title: Tracee Ellis Ross reveals ‘contentious’ relationship with her afro hair
text:
Tracee has a ‘contentious’ relationship with her hair (Picture: WireImage, Tracee Ellis Ross, Instagram)

Tracee Ellis Ross has addressed her tricky relationship with the culture of beauty and admits trying to ‘beat her hair into submission’ to straighten her natural afro curls.

The Black-ish actress, daughter of Diana Ross, is known for her large, beautiful afro mane and pretty much gives us hair envy on a daily basis.

Tracee, 46, is known for embracing her natural hair so it may come as a surprise that she has felt pressured to fit in with society’s standards of beauty.

Speaking to Glamour UK magazine about her relationship with her hair, Tracee said: ‘I went through those teenage years when everybody is searching to figure out who they are and all of a sudden become so aware of how they look, how they are seen, what’s cool, what’s in.

‘Sadly, there were not a tonne of images, outside of my family, of people who looked like me.’

The actress continued: ‘[I had a] contentious relationship with the culture of beauty that was around me, but didn’t make space for me. As a result, I tried to beat my hair into submission to do what I thought it should do. I straightened it, I dyed it, I fried it.’

Feeling noticeably more confident about her hair, Tracee has released her new Pattern Beauty haircare line, which specifically caters to people with 3B to 4C hair types.

Tracee’s launched her own haircare line Pattern Beauty (Picture: Getty Images)

The TV star felt pressure to straighten her curly hair (Picture: WireImage)

Let’s face it, Tracee can rock any hairstyle (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

Which group you fall into, is based on the look, feel and texture of your hair.

But Tracee was surprisingly met with scepticism with some apparently questioning whether she had the ‘credibility’ to start her own haircare line.

‘[The journey] has been fraught with many disappointments, me running up against many of the things that were exactly what made me feel bad about myself,’ Tracee explained.

‘You don’t have the credibility to do this, you need to partner with a professional”, and me attempting to explain that I, like many women of colour and people with curly hair, have become our best experts because the industry has not supported us.’
